I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The Priorities and Action Agenda of the Government of Vanuatu is the current national 
development plan for 2006–2015.1 As the current national development plan ends in 2015, the 
government has started the preparation of a new development plan, and has asked the Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) to assist this process.2 
 
2.  While the government has prior experience in development planning, it is looking to ADB 
to strengthen its capacity in this area. A core team was established to lead the preparation of 
the proposed national sustainable development plan (NSDP). It is made up of representatives 
from the government, civil society, the private sector, academia, and development partners. 
While the NSDP core team will lead the process, ADB will provide technical support to assist the 
Government prepare the NSDP in accordance with sound development planning principles and 
processes. 
 
3.  Government  agencies  and  development  partners  were  consulted  on  the  proposed 
technical  assistance  (TA)  during  the  ADB  workshop  on  the  Vanuatu  country  operations 
business plan, 2015–2017 in Port Vila in March 2014. Consultation with the Department of 
Strategic Policy Planning and Aid Coordination (DSPPAC) and the NSDP core team took place 
during March–May 2014, and the government agreed with the TA as proposed. The design and 
monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.3 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
4.  The Priorities and Action Agenda sets out a national vision for Vanuatu, and is based on 
the need for private-sector-led economic growth and on supporting activities in the primary 
sectors of agriculture, forestry, and fisheries, as well as in tourism. The vision recognizes that 
the government’s role is to create an enabling environment for both domestic and foreign 
investors while ensuring that development is sustainable. 
 
5.  The vision under the current national development plan reflects the need, as expressed 
by the people of Vanuatu, for more employment and income-generating opportunities, for better 
health and education, and for the provision of basic infrastructure for themselves and for their 
children, and also reflects a wish for social stability. The key priority areas under the agenda are 
(i)  private  sector  development  and  employment  creation;  (ii)  macroeconomic  stability  and 
equitable  growth;  (iii)  good  governance  and  public  sector  reform;  (iv)  primary  sector 
development (natural resources and the environment); (v) provision of better basic services, 
especially in rural areas; (vi) education and human resource development; and (vii) economic 
infrastructure and support services.

6.  In February 2013, an update of the agenda was completed.4 This update was based on 
a thorough review of progress in implementing the agenda policies since 2006. The review took 
place  from  2010  to  2012  and  was  conducted  by  the  government  in  consultation  with 
stakeholders and with the assistance from the United Nations Development Programme. 
 
7.  The review found that progress since 2006 had been solid in many areas, but in others 
Vanuatu was falling behind and had lost the momentum for reform. The review found that 
service delivery had not improved in some areas and only slowly in others. It concluded that 
more effort was needed to secure political stability and improve public sector performance. 
 
8.  The proposed NSDP will be developed in the context of an environment of reasonably 
strong economic growth. Vanuatu’s economic performance—driven by tourism, real estate, 
construction, and assistance from development partners—has been robust since 2003. The 
Vanuatu economy achieved its 11th successive year of positive economic growth in 2013. 
Fiscal  management  has  been  sound  and  some  reforms  have  been  introduced.  Future 
performance depends on private sector investment and government investment in infrastructure. 
However, inadequate physical infrastructure, poor governance, an outdated legal and regulatory 
environment  for  private  sector  investment  (although  currently  being  modernized),  and 
government involvement in inefficient enterprises that crowd out the private sector constrain 
private sector development. In addition, the lack of access to affordable capital and the related 
supporting  infrastructure  constrains  the  development  of  the  domestic  private  sector  and 
therefore there is a heavy reliance on foreign direct investment. 
 
9.  Despite this reasonably strong economic growth, Vanuatu is likely to achieve only two of 
the Millennium Development Goals—reducing child mortality (goal 4) and combating HIV/AIDS, 
malaria, and other diseases (goal 6)—by the target date of 2015. Mixed progress is being made 
in eradicating extreme poverty and hunger (goal 1), achieving universal primary education 
(goal 2), promoting gender equality and empowering women (goal 3), and improving maternal 
health (goal 5). Vanuatu is not on track to ensuring environmental sustainability (goal 7).5 The 
NSDP envisages localizing the Millennium Development Goals and going beyond the target 
indicators. 
 
10.  The issues that are of the greatest concern for development planning include inequality 
of income distribution, the poverty of opportunity confronted by much of the population, lack of 
formal employment and income-generating opportunities for school-leavers in the face of rapid 
population growth, and limited access to high-quality education. Environmental and cultural 
sustainability within this development context is also of paramount importance, which is further 
complicated by climate change issues. 
 
11.  About 80% of the population lives in rural areas, although rural–urban drift has led to an 
urban population growth rate of 4% per annum. ADB estimates indicate that by 2020, Vanuatu’s 
urban population will exceed 25% of its total population. Poverty of opportunity is prevalent in 
rural areas where health, education, and transportation facilities are limited and formal sector 
employment  opportunities  lacking,  and  although  traditional  governance  systems  remain 
relatively robust, there is a high risk of these being eroded. In general, urban incomes are higher 
than rural incomes, although a new class of urban poor—particularly in the peri-urban areas—is 
developing. The proposed NSDP will need to consider these issues. In addition, the NSDP will

need to be underpinned by sound planning processes, high levels of stakeholder engagement, 
and effective communication strategies.6 
 
12.  ADB’s country partnership strategy, 2010–2014 for Vanuatu recognizes the importance 
of stronger coordination between stakeholders for the planning and delivery of services in 
Vanuatu, and the need to strengthen the planning capability of key government agencies. The 
TA will directly support the development of Vanuatu’s national and sector priorities for 2016–
2030. 
 
13.  In  preparing  the  TA,  the  following  assumptions  were  made:  (i)  strong  government 
commitment to the preparation of the NSDP, (ii) well-coordinated approach to the preparation of 
the  NSDP  by  all  stakeholders,  and (iii)  strong  commitment  to  and  timely  support from  all 
stakeholders  to  ensure  achievement  of  outputs.  The  following  risks  have  been  identified: 
(i) political instability leading to delays in preparation of the NSDP, and (ii) lack of timely delivery 
of inputs by the government.  
 
14.  A stakeholder analysis drawing on and expanding on the existing stakeholder groups 
that  have  been  identified  by  the  core  group,  and  an  associated  participation  plan  will  be 
prepared to assist with risk mitigation. The stakeholder analysis will help recognize (i) potential 
risks,  conflicts,  and  constraints  that  could  affect  the  NSDP  process;  (ii)  opportunities  and 
partnerships that could be explored and developed; and (iii) vulnerable or marginalized groups 
that are usually left out of the planning process. The associated participation plan will assist in 
guiding stakeholder participation throughout the preparation of the NSDP. The plan captures 
activities and enables their documentation and evaluation.7 
 
III.  THE CAPACITY DEVELOPMENT TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
15.  The impact of the TA will be that the NSDP guides the implementation and monitoring of 
Vanuatu’s  development  vision  and  priorities.  The  outcome  of  the  TA  will  be  stronger 
government capacity for development planning and managing for development results. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
16.  ADB will draw on its experience in development planning in other Pacific countries, and 
will  also  provide  the  technical  skills  and  support  in  planning,  monitoring,  and  evaluation 
processes and systems, to assist in the preparation of the proposed NSDP.8 
 
17.  The TA will deliver the following outputs and associated activities over 2014–2016: 
 
(i)  Strengthened  development  planning  processes.  The  TA  will  support 
DSPPAC and the NSDP core team in the preparation of an NSDP for 2016–2030.

In  particular,  the  TA  will  support  DSPPAC  and  the  NSDP  core  team  to 
(a) organize,  plan,  facilitate,  and  provide  input  for  ministerial  and  sector 
consultations; (b) develop and utilize specific tools to extract policy directives 
from public consultations and feedback sessions and train government personnel 
in the use of such tools; (c) ensure that special interest groups are fully included 
and participate in consultations; (d) ensure that provincial authorities and leaders 
are  given  the  opportunity  to  provide  feedback  on  the  NSDP;  (e)  draft  a 
consultation report, including stakeholder feedback and recommendations on the 
NSDP; and (f) produce a draft NSDP for consideration by the Council of Ministers 
and Parliament.9 
 
(ii)  Strengthened monitoring and evaluation processes and systems. The TA 
will support the government to ensure that appropriate processes and systems 
are in place to implement and monitor the NSDP. 
 
In particular, the TA will work with DSPPAC to establish a framework for regular 
monitoring and reporting against the NSDP, help government agencies to put in 
place the systems to implement and measure achievements under the NSDP, 
and  ensure  that  the  NSDP  is  utilized  as  a  mechanism  for  managing  for 
development results. 
 
18.  The two outputs will support the achievement of the outcome through the provision of 
advice, support, and training on development planning preparation and associated monitoring 
and evaluation. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
19.  The TA is estimated to cost $480,000, of which $400,000 will be financed on a grant 
basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-V). 
 
20.  The government will provide counterpart support in the form of counterpart staff, office 
accommodation,  overhead  costs,  and  other  in-kind  contributions.  The  cost  estimates  and 
financing plan is in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
21.  ADB will be the executing agency and DSPPAC—which is located in the Office of the 
Prime Minister—will be the implementing agency. Disbursements under the TA will be made in 
accordance with ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from 
time to time). 
 
22.  The TA will require international consultants (an estimated 12 person-months of inputs) 
and national consultants (an estimated 16 person-months of inputs) with skills and expertise in 
the formulation of national development plans, monitoring and evaluation, and consultation and 
participation. All consultants will be engaged individually, in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines 
on  the  Use  of  Consultants  (2013,  as  amended  from  time  to  time).  TA  activities  will  be 
implemented over 21 months, from 1 October 2014 to 30 June 2016. The outline terms of 
reference for consultants are in Appendix 3. 
                                                
9  These activities are aligned with the terms of reference for the NSDP core team.

5 
 
23.  The NSDP core team will be responsible for monitoring and evaluating the preparation of 
the  NSDP  and,  accordingly,  this  TA.  Good  practices  and  lessons  will  be  disseminated 
throughout the implementation of the TA. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION 
 
24.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $400,000 on a grant basis to 
the  Government  of  Vanuatu  for  Supporting  the  Preparation  of  the  National  Sustainable 
Development Plan, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  National  sustainable  development  plan  specialist  (international,  approximately  6 
person-months, intermittent). This assignment is intended to provide overall support for the 
preparation of Vanuatu’s proposed national sustainable development plan (NSDP). 
 
2.  The NSDP specialist will have prior experience of working on national development 
planning in a developing country environment. The consultant will have a postgraduate degree 
in economics or other relevant disciplines, and preferably 10 years of relevant work experience. 
The consultant will have strong project management, communication, and writing skills. 
 
3.  The NSDP specialist will (i) support the Department of Strategic Policy Planning and Aid 
Coordination (DSPPAC) and the NSDP core team in the preparation of an NSDP for 2016–2030; 
(ii) support DSPPAC and the NSDP core team in the design, coordination, and facilitation of 
stakeholder engagement and consultations for the development of the NSDP; and (iii) support 
DSPPAC and the NSDP core team in the development and implementation of a plan to raise 
public awareness about the NSDP and its relevance to development issues in Vanuatu. 
 
4.  The specialist will also support the NSDP core team to ensure that special interest and 
disadvantaged groups—including women, women’s groups, community-based organizations, 
non-government organizations working with women, the Department of Women’s Affairs, and 
gender  focal  points  in  sector  ministries  (if  any)—are  consulted  and  participate  during 
preparation of the NSDP. 
 
5.  The expected outputs are (i) completion of stakeholder engagement and consultations 
for  the  development  of  the  NSDP,  (ii)  an  NSDP  for  2016–2030,  and  (iii)  completion  and 
implementation of a plan to raise public awareness about the NSDP and its relevance to 
development issues in Vanuatu. 
 
6.  In undertaking this role, the NSDP specialist will (i) coordinate the work of the other 
consultants engaged under the technical assistance (TA); (ii) ensure that the TA is implemented 
in line with a work plan agreed with DSPPAC, the NSDP core team, and the Asian Development 
Bank,  and  according  to  the  terms  of  reference  and  contract  provisions  for  consultants; 
(iii) prepare brief monthly update reports on work performed; (iv) prepare a brief inception report, 
draft final report, and final report in a format satisfactory to DSPPAC, the NSDP core team, and 
the Asian Development Bank; (v) work with the NSDP core team to coordinate organization of 
the  consultation  and  stakeholder  engagement  forums;  and  (vi)  take  responsibility  for  the 
collective work of the consulting team as well as for coordinating and liaising with stakeholders. 
 
7.  Planning specialist (national, approximately 10 person-months, intermittent). Working 
closely with the national sustainable development plan specialist (international), this assignment 
is intended to provide support for the preparation of Vanuatu’s proposed NSDP. 
 
8.  The planning specialist will ideally have prior experience in working on development 
planning in Vanuatu. The consultant will have a post graduate degree in economics or another 
relevant discipline, and preferably 5 years of relevant work experience. The consultant will have 
strong project management, communication, and writing skills. Expertise in gender and social 
inclusion is desirable. 
 
9.  The  planning  specialist  will  (i)  support  DSPPAC  and  the  NSDP  core  team  in  the 
preparation of an NSDP for 2016–2030; (ii) support DSPPAC and the NSDP core team in the

to the Directors, DSPPAC, NSDP focal points in the line ministries, and the Secretary–Generals

the areas outside of Port Vila.

18.  The consultation and participation specialist will ideally have experience in development 
planning and leading participatory consultation processes. The consultant will have a degree in 
economics or another relevant discipline, and at least 5 years of relevant work experience. The 
consultant will have strong project management, communication, and writing skills. Expertise in 
gender and social inclusion is desirable. 
 
19.  The consultation and participation specialist will carry out the following tasks: 
 
(i)  Prepare a stakeholder analysis and associated participation plan. The stakeholder 
analysis will help identify (a) potential risks, conflicts, and constraints that could affect 
the NSDP process; (b) opportunities and partnerships that could be explored and 
developed; and (c) vulnerable or marginalized groups that are usually left out of 
planning  processes.  An  associated  participation  plan  will  assist  in  guiding 
stakeholder participation through the preparation of the NSDP. The plan captures 
activities and enables their documentation and evaluation. 
(ii) Work  with  DSPPAC  and  the  NSDP  core  team  to  organize,  plan,  facilitate,  and 
provide input to the consultation and stakeholder engagement forums planned for the 
preparation of the proposed NSDP. 
(iii) Prepare reports summarizing the consultation and stakeholder engagement forums 
for input into the NSDP. 
 
20.  The specialist will also ensure that special interest and disadvantaged groups—including 
women,  women’s  groups,  community-based  organizations,  nongovernment  organizations 
working with women, the Department of Women’s Affairs, and gender focal points in sector 
ministries (if any)—are consulted and participate during preparation of the NSDP. 
 
21.  In undertaking this role, the consultation and participation specialist will (i) work closely 
with the other consultants engaged under the TA; (ii) prepare brief monthly update reports on 
work performed; and (iii) provide input into the inception report, draft final report, and final report 
prepared by the NSDP specialist.
